posts.name: John
posts.cooked: In Windows 10, I selected 2 language packs for my Windows 10 installation and since I did that, other apps that use the Windows spell checker use both languages for the spell checker (English and German), but Signal Desktop doesn‚Äôt. Is there a way to do this or do you plan to implement this? I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm the only one here who uses more than one language to communicate with people, especially if English is not your first language, you may be constantly switching between your language and English.

posts.name: Georg Umgiesser
posts.cooked: I strongly support this request. This is the one and only reason why I am still not moving away from whatsapp web application, where in my browser I have easy access to more than one language. It is easy to switch, correct wrong spelling, etc‚Ä¶ This is what I would really like to have in Signal.

I too strongly support this request. I also have the English and German (Swiss) language packs installed on my Windows 10 machine but Signal‚Äôs spell check only works if I‚Äôm writing in German. So I did a little sleuthing it appears that Signal‚Äôs spellcheck downloads its own dictionaries. In my case only the German language dictionary is downloaded on my machine (de-DE-3-0.bdic). I have no idea why this dictionary and not the English one or any other one for that matter. There is a configuration file called ‚Äúpreferences‚Äù in Signal‚Äôs root directory with the following statement {‚Äúspellcheck‚Äù:{‚Äúdictionaries‚Äù:[‚Äúde‚Äù],‚Äúdictionary‚Äù:""}} . I suspect that If the English dictionary were also installed, then this statement could be modified to include [‚Äúen‚Äù] but I‚Äôm just guessing here. I have turned off spell check right now, but I‚Äôd really appreciate if I could turn it back on. I‚Äôm willing to manually select German or English. Thanks in advance for addressing this problem.

posts.name: Martin
posts.cooked: Running Signal 1.39.6 on latest Windows 10, there‚Äôs no preferences named file within its root folder (C:\Users\[UserName]\AppData\Local\Programs\signal-desktop) on my machine - where‚Äôs yours installed?

posts.name: Martin
posts.cooked:
@m-i-k-e-y Thanks for that!

Meanwhile, I‚Äôve found another location of that file: C:\Users\root\AppData\Local\CEF\User Data\Dictionaries
Inside that folder, there‚Äôs another dictionary file, en-US-9-0.bdic, but copying it over into Signal‚Äôs Dictionaries folder & modifying the spellchecker array to, e. g. "spellcheck":{"dictionaries":["de","en-us"],"dictionary":""} didn‚Äôt allow for multiple spellchecking at once either‚Ä¶

posts.name: Jan Meijnaerts
posts.cooked:
I have the same problem with languages English and Dutch
Signal language is in Dutch, but spelling checker language comes always only for the English language which is the wrong language
A choice between lnguages could solve this

posts.name: Jan Meijnaerts
posts.cooked: I tried also to update the spellchecker in the preferences file, but it seems that this file is regenerated at restart of the signal app, overwriting what i edited before

posts.name: Lonie8499
posts.cooked: This is a big disadvantage for me too, I am Swiss-German, live in Czech rep., my Windows OS is in EN, but I write in CZ, DE, FR and EN. With the WhatsApp Web Client, I can choose the spell checker from Chrome including the extended Plug-In.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm changed the language of my Windows to English, but I would like to enable also German check spelling.
The option to disable spell checking would also be welcome. At least for me.

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

The option to disable spell checking would also be welcome.

It‚Äôs already available, you can configure it via Signal Desktop Preferences > Enable spell check.

posts.name: Knttr
posts.cooked:
I also support this request, albeit for the Linux desktop version.
Spelling is a major issue for me as a dyslexic person. I regularly write in 3 languages and end up doing copy and paste from an editor that does spellcheck.

posts.name: Kierun
posts.cooked:
Original GitHub issue where there is quiet a lot of comments.

When you speak different languages depending on the contact / situation, being able to switch is an important feature. Additional features are:

  • The ability to load and list multiple dictionaries.
  • The ability to switch which one is used.
  • Instructions on how to install additional dictionaries.

A special use case I use is speaking two different languages in the same chat so having a per chat setting would be useless. Could you have true multiple language support? So, check (say) en_GB then fr_FR ‚Ä¶

+1 from me, too. I‚Äôm regularly using English and German languages. However, restarting the desktop app everytime I switch the conversation isn‚Äôt a really workable/usable solution (cf. KwadroNaut‚Äôs reply in the old issue in github)

AND

A special use case I use is speaking two different languages in the same chat so having a per chat setting would be useless. Could you have true multiple language support? So, check (say) en_GB then fr_FR ‚Ä¶

Actually, I think speaking or writing multiple languages in the same chat is a very important feature, especially when you‚Äôre chatting with people not having the same mother‚Äôs tongue than you, for me a lot of my coworkers are from Spain, living here in Germany. We‚Äôre regularly switching between German and English (sometimes Spanish, too).

It‚Äôs now possible to get spell check for multiple languages, in the Flatpak install you can do this with: flatpak override --user --env=LANGUAGE=en_US.UTF-8:nl_NL.UTF-8 org.signal.Signal for Dutch and English.

posts.name: R
posts.cooked:
Thank you! Works like a charm. By the way for anyone interested, this can also be achieved with non-Flatpak installs:

LANGUAGE=en_US.UTF-8:nl_NL.UTF-8 signal-desktop
This worked perfectly for me! And seeing that there was a non-Flatpak solution offered, this definitely sounds like a preference that can be built directly into the desktop app.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
glad someone bumped this thread because it works like a charm.
for those who don‚Äôt know how (or don‚Äôt want) to work with the command line, it is possible your desktop environment offers a graphical application editor for inserting environment variables. this is for example how to do it on KDE Plasma‚Äôs ‚ÄúMenu Editor‚Äù (which despite the name, isn‚Äôt just for the menu):
